definitions: make a rough whirring or vibrating sound like certain machinery or tools
remove rough edges or projections from metal or other materials using tools
examples: The old motor burs loudly when starting on cold mornings
His speech burs with a thick Scottish accent after drinking
The machinist carefully burred the metal edges before final assembly
You need to bur these sharp corners for safety reasons

definitions: imitate something or someone in an exaggerated way to make fun of them
examples: The comedian burlesqued the politician's awkward gestures during the show
They burlesqued the serious opera by adding silly dance moves

definitions: speak with a rough rolling pronunciation of the letter r
make a continuous rough whirring or vibrating sound like machinery
examples: She burrs her words with a distinctive Edinburgh accent
The actor learned to burr authentically for the Scottish character
The drill burrs against the metal creating tiny sparks
The coffee grinder burrs as it processes the beans

definitions: dig a hole or tunnel in the ground as animals do for shelter
search for something by digging through or moving things around persistently
examples: Rabbits burrow deep into the hillside to create their homes
The groundhog burrowed under our garden shed last winter
She burrowed through the old boxes looking for family photos
He burrowed into the pile of documents seeking evidence

definitions: perform music or entertainment in public places for voluntary donations from passersby
examples: The guitar player busks near the subway entrance every evening
Young musicians often busk downtown to earn extra money

definitions: break something forcefully causing it to separate into pieces or stop working
arrest or catch someone doing something illegal especially by police
fail completely or go out of business especially suddenly
examples: The kids busted the window playing baseball in the yard
Don't bust the lock trying to force it open
Police busted the drug dealers in an early morning raid
The security guard busted teenagers trying to sneak into movies
The restaurant busted after only six months in business
Many tech startups bust within their first year

definitions: move around in a busy energetic way doing many things quickly
examples: Servers bustled between tables during the dinner rush
She bustled around the kitchen preparing for the party

definitions: cut up and prepare meat for sale or cooking as a profession
do something very badly or carelessly ruining it in the process
examples: He learned to butcher cattle at his family's meat shop
The chef butchered the whole lamb for the feast
The singer completely butchered the national anthem at the game
Don't let him butcher your hair at that salon

definitions: swim using the butterfly stroke with both arms moving together overhead
cut something almost in half and open it flat like butterfly wings
examples: She butterflies gracefully across the pool during practice
Olympic swimmers butterfly at incredible speeds in competitions
The chef butterflied the chicken breast before grilling it
Butterfly the shrimp by cutting along the back

definitions: make a low continuous humming sound like bees or electrical equipment
move quickly and busily from place to place with energy
spread news or rumors quickly through informal communication channels
examples: Bees buzz loudly around the flowering cherry tree
The broken fluorescent light buzzes annoyingly overhead
Waiters buzz between tables during the lunch rush
Children buzz excitedly around the playground after school
Rumors buzz through the office about upcoming layoffs
News of the celebrity sighting buzzed through social media

definitions: work together secretly to plan something especially against someone in power
examples: The ministers caballed to remove the prime minister from office
Executives caballed behind closed doors about the merger

definitions: hide or store something in a secret place for later use
store data temporarily in computer memory for faster access later
examples: Squirrels cache nuts throughout the forest for winter
The explorers cached supplies along their planned return route
The browser caches frequently visited websites for faster loading
Our system caches search results to improve response times

definitions: carry a golfer's clubs and give advice during a golf game
examples: He caddied for professional golfers during summer tournaments
Would you like someone to caddie for you today

definitions: work as a caddie carrying golf clubs for players on a course
examples: She caddies at the country club on weekends
Many teenagers caddy to earn money during summer

definitions: adjust measuring instruments or equipment to ensure they give accurate readings
examples: Technicians calibrate the scales every morning before opening
You must calibrate the thermometer before taking measurements

definitions: measure the dimensions of objects using caliper tools with adjustable arms
examples: The engineer calipered each part to ensure precise measurements
Carefully caliper the diameter before cutting the metal

definitions: make someone become emotionally hardened and insensitive through repeated negative experiences
examples: Years of rejection calloused him against romantic relationships
Working in emergency medicine can callous doctors to suffering

definitions: build or shape something with a slight curve or arch especially in roads
examples: Engineers camber the road surface to help water drain
The carpenter cambered the beam to support more weight

definitions: hide or disguise something by making it look like its surroundings
examples: Soldiers camouflage themselves with paint and leafy branches
The chameleon camouflages itself by changing color

definitions: construct artificial waterways for transportation irrigation or drainage purposes
examples: Engineers canaled through the desert to bring water
They plan to canal this area for better drainage

definitions: beat or punish someone using a long thin stick as punishment
support plants by tying them to long thin sticks or poles
examples: Teachers used to cane students for misbehavior decades ago
The headmaster threatened to cane boys who broke rules
Gardeners cane tomato plants to help them grow upright
You should cane these roses before they get too tall

definitions: cause something to become corrupted infected or decayed spreading like disease
examples: Jealousy cankered their friendship over the years
Corruption cankers the political system from within

definitions: fire large heavy guns repeatedly especially in warfare or ceremonies
collide with great force bouncing off like a ball
examples: Artillery units cannoned the enemy fortress all night
Ships cannoned each other during the naval battle
The car cannoned off the barrier into oncoming traffic
Players cannoned into each other chasing the ball

definitions: travel in a narrow lightweight boat using paddles to move through water
examples: We canoed down the peaceful river all afternoon
They plan to canoe across the lake tomorrow

definitions: cover an area with a protective overhead structure or natural covering
examples: Trees canopy the forest path keeping it cool
They canopied the outdoor market with colorful fabric

definitions: tilt or lean something at an angle from the vertical position
speak using insincere religious or moral language to deceive others
examples: Workers cant the beams to provide better support
The ship canted dangerously in the storm
Politicians often cant about family values before elections
The preacher cants endlessly but lives differently

definitions: ride a horse at a moderate pace faster than trot but slower than gallop
examples: She cantered her horse along the beach at sunset
Riders canter around the track during warm-up exercises

definitions: build or extend a structure horizontally beyond its vertical support creating overhang
examples: Architects cantilevered the deck over the cliff edge
The bridge cantilevers dramatically across the deep ravine

definitions: skip or dance about in a lively playful way showing excitement or joy
examples: Children caper around the playground during recess
The puppies capered happily when their owner returned home

definitions: write or print letters in their upper case or capital form
use a situation or opportunity to gain advantage or profit from it
examples: Remember to capitalise the first word of every sentence
You must capitalise all proper nouns in formal writing
Smart businesses capitalise on new market trends quickly
She capitalised on her opponent's mistakes to win

definitions: write or print letters in their upper case or capital form
use a situation or opportunity to gain advantage or profit from it
provide money or financial resources to start or expand a business
examples: Always capitalize names of countries and cities
Don't forget to capitalize the beginning of sentences
Companies must capitalize on emerging technologies to survive
The team capitalized on their rival's defensive errors
Investors agreed to capitalize the startup with ten million
Banks refused to capitalize the risky venture

definitions: stop resisting and surrender accepting the terms or demands of an opponent
examples: The surrounded army finally capitulated after weeks of siege
Management capitulated to union demands after the strike

definitions: overturn a boat or ship in water so that it turns upside down
examples: Strong winds capsized several sailboats during the race
The overloaded ferry capsized in rough seas

definitions: put something in a small container or covering for protection or preservation
examples: Scientists capsule time-sensitive samples for space experiments
The museum capsules delicate artifacts in protective cases

definitions: add descriptive text to pictures videos or illustrations explaining what they show
examples: Please caption all photos before uploading them online
The editor captioned each illustration with relevant information

definitions: attract and hold someone's attention completely through charm beauty or excellence
examples: The magician captivated audiences with impossible illusions
Her storytelling captivates children for hours

definitions: travel together in a group especially through dangerous or difficult areas
examples: Merchants caravanned across the desert for safety
Families caravan together to the music festival annually

definitions: draw or describe someone with greatly exaggerated features for comic effect
examples: Political cartoonists caricature world leaders in newspapers
The comedian caricatured the celebrity's unusual mannerisms

definitions: sing joyful religious songs especially Christmas songs going from place to place
examples: Children carol door to door collecting donations for charity
The choir carols at nursing homes during the holidays

definitions: complain constantly about trivial matters in an annoying persistent way
examples: He carps about every little detail in meetings
Stop carping about the weather and enjoy the trip

definitions: build or repair wooden structures and objects using specialized tools and skills
examples: He carpentered custom cabinets for the new kitchen
She carpenters furniture in her workshop on weekends

definitions: turn sideways with hands on ground and legs rotating over like wheel spokes
examples: Gymnasts cartwheel across the mat during floor routines
Children love to cartwheel on the soft grass

definitions: fall or hang down in large quantities like water flowing over rocks
examples: Water cascades over the cliff creating a beautiful waterfall
Her long hair cascaded down her back

definitions: make a systematic list of items with descriptions for reference or sale
examples: Librarians catalog new books as they arrive
The museum catalogs every artifact in its collection
